head.title: Advertising to the Young, At Whose Ultimate Cost?

hedline.hl1: Advertising to the Young, At Whose Ultimate Cost?

abstract.p: Iris Kaufman letter responds to Fred Brock's July 2 Seniority column on advertising industry's targeting of young consumers, despite growing wealth and numbers of older consumers; finds advertisers are focusing on population that is forming brand loyalties and buying first homes (M)

block.p: In ''A Madison Avenue Fantasy,'' (Seniority, July 2), Fred Brock discussed the advertising industry's continuing emphasis on young consumers, despite the greater wealth and increasing numbers of older adults. The column drew varied responses from readers.

In ''A Madison Avenue Fantasy,'' (Seniority, July 2), Fred Brock discussed the advertising industry's continuing emphasis on young consumers, despite the greater wealth and increasing numbers of older adults. The column drew varied responses from readers.

In wondering why ''Network Row and Madison Avenue think young eyeballs are worth more to them than older ones,'' Mr. Brock cited statistics comparing net worth and future populations of young and old. His point was that advertisers are ''aiming where the money increasingly isn't.''

In fact, advertisers are focusing on the population that is forming brand loyalties in products, services and entertainment as well as buying first homes. That is in contrast with my own household, which consists of two people over 60 (with money), disinclined to try new products and with very limited needs for new acquisitions.
Simply put, advertisers know what they're doing.
